title: Trump’s German frenemy
text:
BERLIN — When word spread earlier this year that Germany’s most important transatlantic lobbying group planned to nominate Sigmar Gabriel, a prominent Russia-friendly socialist, as its next leader, many in the German capital thought it was a bad joke.

Largely unknown outside of Germany, Atlantik Brücke ("Atlantic Bridge") was founded in 1952 by prominent bankers and politicians to foster transatlantic exchange. Since then, it has counted as one of Germany’s most exclusive clubs with a membership that has included the likes of Helmut Kohl and Angela Merkel, as well as the CEOs of the country’s largest companies.

Given that history, many wondered why the German political and business elites behind Atlantik Brücke would risk making the already fraught relationship with the U.S. even worse by choosing as its leader someone who, as a German minister, had been a vocal critic of U.S. policy on everything from the Middle East to Russia.

“He would be a disaster,” one veteran member told POLITICO when Gabriel’s name first emerged in February.

Gabriel’s boosters argued he is one of the few available Germans with the stature to fulfill the prominent role. The longtime leader of the Social Democrats, Gabriel held the position of vice chancellor and served as economy and then foreign minister in Merkel’s Cabinet, leaving the latter job after a party power struggle in 2018.

Can a provocateur like Gabriel (he once referred to Israel as an “apartheid regime”) effectively lead the debate?

Ultimately, the weight of his résumé prevailed and Gabriel, 59, won approval as Atlantik Brücke’s chairman by a clear majority in late June, overcoming a last-minute mini revolt by some members.

Even so, doubts about his suitability for the role continue to dog him.

In a recent interview over sandwiches at Atlantik Brücke headquarters, which is housed in a small baroque palace overlooking Berlin’s museum quarter, Gabriel made clear he thrives on the tension.

“What drew me to this job is that the relationship is so difficult at the moment,” he said.

But can a provocateur like Gabriel (he once referred to Israel an “apartheid regime”) effectively lead the debate?

His supporters say yes, arguing that with Trump as president, appointing the outspoken Gabriel to fight Germany’s corner could turn out to be a masterstroke.

While Gabriel stressed that Atlantik Brücke isn’t a substitute government, its role as an informal forum, where leaders from both sides of the Atlantic can quietly meet and discuss the issues of the day, arguably makes the group more important than ever.

Once a year, for example, NATO’s supreme allied commander visits Atlantik Brücke to debate security priorities with members and the German army’s senior officers. Topping the agenda in recent years has been Russia, a subject with which Gabriel is quite familiar.

Just not in the way Washington would like.

Whether the question is Russian sanctions, which Gabriel has suggested loosening, or the controversial Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline, which he endorses, Gabriel's position is typically at odds with that of the U.S.

After Moscow confiscated a Ukrainian ship and took its crew prisoner in the Kerch Strait last fall, Gabriel accused Kiev, which had asked for Western support, of “trying to drag us into a war.”

Russia, right or wrong

A protégé of Gerhard Schröder, the former German chancellor who now works for state-owned Russian gas giant Gazprom and is a close friend of Vladimir Putin, Gabriel adheres to the traditional view of his Social Democratic Party that no matter how bad things get, engaging Russia is preferable to isolating it.

Gabriel insists his true allegiance lies with the U.S., which he says is and should remain Germany's most important partner outside Europe.

His soft approach to Russia — Gabriel joined Schröder and Putin for dinner in St. Petersburg in 2017 and is one of the few German politicians to grant interviews to Kremlin-backed media outlet RT — has earned him a reputation for being a Russlandversteher, a German pejorative for sympathizers of Putin’s Russia.

It’s a label he wears with pride.

“My hope would be that anyone involved in international politics would try to understand the countries they’re talking to,” he said.

He also pointed out his record of publicly standing up to Russia when it comes to defending Western values. During a tense press conference in Moscow with Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov in 2017, for example, Gabriel offered a spirited defense of Western democracy and cautioned Russia not to intervene in democratic elections.

Gabriel, who grew up in West Germany within sight of the East German border, insists his true allegiance lies with the U.S., which he says is and should remain Germany's most important partner outside Europe.

“I come from a generation that still knows how much we owe to the Americans,” he said, recalling his childhood and service as a German soldier in the state of Lower Saxony. “We didn’t feel in danger and that was because we knew there was someone there to guarantee our freedom.”

Even though he remains deeply critical of Donald Trump’s decision to withdraw from the Iran nuclear deal and his overall treatment of U.S. allies, Gabriel said he supports some aspects of the American president’s agenda, which he believes many of his compatriots are too quick to dismiss.

"It’s not the case that everything Trump says is false,” he said, pointing to Trump’s efforts to negotiate a peace deal with North Korea. “It’s worth considering the substance of what he’s saying instead of taking the easy route and just getting upset over the way he expresses himself.”

Case in point: Germany’s trade surplus, the world’s largest. Trump (along with the International Monetary Fund, the OECD and the European Commission) has lambasted Germany for failing to temper its export surpluses, which critics argue contribute to global imbalances.

“The OECD and the Americans are absolutely right about the imbalances on trade and finance,” Gabriel said. “There’s only one group of economists that has argued for 20 years that the trade surplus is positive and funnily enough they all speak German.”

Don't blame Trump

Gabriel said Germans are wrong to blame Trump alone for the shift in the transatlantic relationship, arguing that the roots run much deeper. After the Cold War, it was inevitable that the U.S. would at some point begin to shift its attention to other priorities, such as China.

“Now we have an American president who says things can’t continue in the same way they’ve been for the past 70 years, but we could have figured that out earlier,” he said.

So far, such overtures have failed to impress U.S. officials, who remain skeptical of Gabriel’s record of opposing higher German defense spending (he has called NATO's 2 percent of GDP defense spending target "absurd") and what they view as his cozy relationship with Putin.

Gabriel sought the endorsement of U.S. Ambassador Richard Grenell during his run for the Atlantik Brücke post but was rebuffed. The two haven’t spoken since.

“Here is the real problem: In contrast to every other president before him, Trump has created the impression that partnership amongst equals isn’t desired” — Sigmar Gabriel

Last week, Gabriel suggested Grenell is ill-suited for the role as ambassador, telling Der Spiegel that Germany needs a U.S. ambassador who could act as a "facilitator" and explain Berlin's viewpoint to Washington.

Relations between Atlantik Brücke and the Trump administration were frosty long before Gabriel arrived on the scene, however. As a bastion of the German establishment, the Atlantik Brücke represents the very “globalist” forces Trump built his presidential campaign opposing.

Asked by a German newspaper for his opinion of Grenell, Friedich Merz, a conservative politician who preceded Gabriel as Atlantik Brücke chief, responded: “I have nothing to say about this man.”

Not on the record, anyway. Atlantik Brücke’s leadership was so frustrated by the Trump administration’s refusal to engage with them that they bestowed their most prestigious honor, the Eric Warburg Prize, named for one the group’s founders, on Canadian Foreign Minister Chrystia Freeland in December. It is the first time the award had gone to a Canadian in its 30-year history.

Gabriel said the only way to repair the transatlantic bond is to reinvent it. That means Europe, and Germany in particular, will have to take more initiative. Even then, U.S. engagement in Europe remains essential.

“Here is the real problem: In contrast to every other president before him, Trump has created the impression that partnership amongst equals isn’t desired,” Gabriel said. “I would answer that the idea of having partners and allies has been the multiplier of American power for more than 70 years. That is the reason I think that President Trump’s bowling-alone strategy is not in the interest of the U.S. and its citizens.”

The deep business and cultural ties should compel both sides to continue to work closely together, despite the changing nature of the relationship, Gabriel argued. To hope, as some Germans do, things would “return to normal” if Trump loses the 2020 election was unrealistic, he added. Amid the shifting global power dynamics, the U.S. will inevitably become less focused on Europe.

“My hope is that Germany and Europe will take on more responsibility and there will be a true partnership with the U.S. based on trust, not on blind devotion,” he said.
description: Sigmar Gabriel’s ties to Russia make him an unlikely bridge between Berlin and Washington.
